pr_title: Processing Raw Platforms Configs From the Plugins

timeline.bodyText: @chanseokoh my tests have been failing because this code block is not catching a platform that has either os or architecture as null.Is there any way of ensuring that when either os/arch is null , this method throws an exception

timeline.bodyText:
Not just missing a field but also for the case with an invalid/unknown value. For example, some invalid value other than "linux", "windows", etc. So, how about
"if the specified platform list is missing required fields or has invalid values"
?

timeline.bodyText: Don't use platform.toString() but use an actual String literal to verify the returned value.

timeline.bodyText:
How about from.platforms misses a required field or has an invalid value: ?
Note it's from.platforms.

timeline.bodyText: <from><platforms> We use brackets for Maven.
timeline.author: chanseokoh

timeline.bodyText:
platformConfiguration.toString() will returns some weird string value (for example, PlatformConfiguration@6d06d69c), unless the class (or any of its super-classes) overrode and implemented toString().
And I think we don't want to implement toString() in PlatformConfiguration implementations. So probably we should assemble a human-readable string form here. For example,
"architecture=" + platformConfiguration.getArchitectureName().orElse("<missing>") + ", os=" + platformConfiguration.getOsName().orElse("<missing>")
timeline.author: chanseokoh

+  /**
+   * Parses the list of platforms to a set of {@link Platform}.
+   *
+   * @param rawConfiguration raw configuration data
+   * @return the set of parsed platforms
+   * @throws InvalidPlatformConfigurationException if there exists a platformConfiguration in the
+   *     specified platforms list that is missing required fields or has invalid values
+   */
+  @VisibleForTesting
+  static Set<Platform> getPlatformsSet(RawConfiguration rawConfiguration)
+      throws InvalidPlatformConfigurationException {
+    Set<Platform> platforms = new LinkedHashSet<>();
+    for (PlatformConfiguration platformConfiguration : rawConfiguration.getPlatforms()) {
+
+      String platformToString =
+          "architecture="
+              + platformConfiguration.getArchitectureName().orElse("<missing>")
+              + ", os="
+              + platformConfiguration.getOsName().orElse("<missing>");
+
+      if (!platformConfiguration.getArchitectureName().isPresent()) {
+        throw new InvalidPlatformConfigurationException(
+            "platform configuration is missing an architecture value",
+            platformToString,
+            new IllegalArgumentException());

replies.bodyText:
We can remove Throwable cause from the contructor, as we don't get any exception from another party.
  InvalidPlatformConfigurationException(String message, String platform, Throwable cause) {
And for consistency, let's rename the exception class to InvalidPlatformException. And when you rename it, you need to update all the Javadocs too.
And because now we are ensure that getArchitectureName() and getOsName() are always present, there is no need to catch NoSuchElementException that will never be thrown. Remove the try-catch block below.
replies.author: chanseokoh

timeline.bodyText: I'm pretty sure you can remove throws InvalidPlatformException in this method (since you are catching it with try-catch).
timeline.author: chanseokoh

timeline.bodyText: I'm pretty sure you can remove throws InvalidPlatformException in this method (since you are catching it with try-catch).
timeline.author: chanseokoh

timeline.bodyText:
So, I see we have a difference from other Invalid*Exception in that we are passing a better exception messages when instantiating InvalidPlatformException. But then, we are not making use of the exception message. In this case, I think we can show a more helpful and detailed message to the user by
"from.platforms contains a platform configuration that is missing required values or has invalid values: " + ex.getMessage() + ": " + ex.getInvalidPlatform()
Note "platformConfiguration" --> "platform configuration". The message will be shown to the end user, and platformConfiguration is an internal Java variable name in our code that the user doesn't know about. Similarly, I think "required values" is more appropriate for the end user.
timeline.author: chanseokoh
